msItem.note: Two modern hands have numbered the sections implied by the drop capitals in ink and pencil as chapters 1–98. A contemporary hand indicates nine readings within the text, each of which ends with the annotation Tu autem in the margin if it is not immediately followed by another lection. Lectio 1, fols 1vb–2ra, ch. 1, Scripturus itaque … tuorum super omnia aromata; 2, fols 2vb–3rb, chs. 5–6, Cum igitur … remanerent uestigia; 3, fols 3ra–4ra, ch. 8, Erat in uico quodam … ipsa rerum experientia didicimus; 4, fol. 4ra–va, chap. 9, Per idem tempus … et tedio affecerat inmanitas; 5, fols 6vb–7va, chap. 20, Ad laudem insuper diuine pietatis … ubi munus curationis acceperat; 6, fols 7vb–8rb, chap. 22, Hoc quoque relatu … prorsus et inmunem; 7, chap. 23, fols 8rb–9ra, Sed et de hoc quod eodem die … reformante momentis; 8, fols 9vb–10ra, Puella quedam Emelina nomine … et corpore herens et affectu (opening indicator erased); 9, fols 15ra–va(?), Nec uacat a laude uirginis … sue testimonio roborantes (no Tu autem).

supportDesc.collation: a2, 1–38 (fols 1–24), 46–1+1 (fols 25–30; 3rd replaced), b2 The first leaf of each quire is lettered a–d at the foot, in 16th- or 17th-century ink. deseruire uiderentur

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in pencil and plummet; pricking on all edges of the page for frame and lines, spaced 5.5 mm apart. Horizontal rules occur from top to bottom (fol. 2r) at 33.5 | 39 | 44.5 | 21.75 | 207 | 212.75 | 273; vertical rules, from left to right, 20 | 24 | 79.5 | 84 | 88.5 | 142 | 146.5 | 191.5. Written above top line.

handDesc.handNote: Gothic script. At least three scribes.

Fols 28vb–30rb are written in a darker shade of ink, likely a slightly later addition. The same shade of ink is used to make numerous corrections to the text, particularly adding punctuation to assist oral reading (sometimes the additions are overpunctuated in comparison to the original text).

decoDesc.decoNote: Text opens with an 8-line arabesque initial in red and green. Subsequent chapters open with 2-line initials, generally alternating between blue and red.

Along with letters added plummet to direct the rubricator, there are numbers whose function is unclear: iii in the margin of fol. 10rb; iii, fol. 17rb; iiii, fol. 17va; iii, fol. 18ra; iiii and viii, fol. 18rb.

binding.p: Standard Digby binding (Delisle type I). Brass clasps.
binding.decoNote: Decorated with Digby’s arms, surrounded by wreath, with legend INSIGNIA KENELMI DIGBY EQVITIS AVRATI ✠.

history.origin: St Frideswide’s Priory, Oxford (OSA), with at least the manuscript’s first two quires (fols 1–16) written in 1180–1183. A modification of a passage of John the Scot, bishop-elect of St Andrews, to reflect his resignation of this position in June 1183 (ch. 1) establishes this date. A reference to Roger, the abbot of Abingdon, who died in 1185 (ch. 42) reinforces it. The manuscript includes what appear to be autograph revisions to the text rather than corrections from an exemplar, most notably in his account of the translation of Frideswide’s relics on fol. 2ra, and what appears to be an extended addition at the foot of fols 15v–16r. The text at fols 28vb–30rb appears to be a slightly later addition. The series of nine readings in the margins suggest extended liturgical use that would not likely have occurred outside of Oxford.
history.provenance: Thomas Allen (MS fº 7); Allen/Digby inventory A 14: pressmarks and signature on fol. 1r. Many of Allen’s manuscripts were from Oxford.
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian by Kenelm Digby (his motto, Vindica te tibi, and signature on fol. 1r).

supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in modern pencil, 1–131. Medieval foliation, 3–127 (fols 6–131, skipping fol. 23).
supportDesc.collation: 1one (fol. 1) | 24 (fols 2–5) | 36 (fols 6–11), 4–188 (fols 12–131). Missing one or two quires at the end.

history.origin: England, first half of the 14th century.
history.provenance: The Benedictine nunnery of Sts Mary and Elfleda, Romsey, Hampshire: late 14th-century inscription, Romesey, which also annotates the life of Elfleda (fols 43v–45v), which mentions the abbey (fol. 43v); late 15th-century inscription Iste liber est de librario ecclesie sancte Marie et sancte Etheflede uirginis. de Romesey (fol. 1r).
Sir James Ware. See William O’Sullivan, A Finding List of Sir James Ware’s Manuscripts, p. 81.
Robert Ware, the youngest son of James: inherited the manuscripts on his father’s death in 1666.
Henry Hyde, second earl of Clarendon. His manuscript no. 30. Purchased the Ware manuscripts from Robert in 1686 while he was lord lieutenant of Ireland.
Tenison’s public library at St Martin’s-in-the-Fields, London. Deposited there by Clarendon in 1687.
Edward Bernard, who catalogued the Ware manuscripts before 1694: initials E.B. with Heb Dhun, heb dhim (fol. 1r).
Henry Hyde, second earl of Clarendon: removed most of his collection from St Martin’s in 1692–94. J.P. no. 54 (fol. 1r) appears to be a new accession number, according to O’Sullivan, p. 75.
Christopher Bateman: prepared Clarendon books for sale after death in 1709; no. 213?
James Brydges, first duke of Chandos: purchased Clarendon’s library in 1709.
James West: purchased at the Duke of Chandos sale, 12 March 1746/47, lot 2292.
KKf, replaced with LLf (fol. 1r), referring to a price? Other inscriptions and scribbles.
history.acquisition: William Petty, second earl of Shelburne and first marquess of Lansdowne. Purchased by the British Museum together with 1244 other Lansdowne manuscripts in 1807.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Benedicta Ward, SLG, translated Prior Philip’s Miracles of St Frideswide while researching her doctoral thesis under R.W. Southern, Miracles and Miracle Collections, 1015–1215 (University of Oxford, 1978), which she later published as Miracles and the Medieval Mind (1982). The text and the need for a new edition came to Andrew Dunning’s attention while surveying the authors and possible manuscripts from St Frideswide’s Priory during 2016–17, when he was a Royal Bank of Canada Foundation fellow at the Bodleian Library’s Centre for the Study of the Book and later a curator at the British Library.

We learned of our mutual interest in this work through the acquaintance of Ruth Buckley, a retired medical practitioner with an interest in the legacy of St Frideswide and the history of medicine. This complete edition and translation would not have come together without her encouragement and insight. The text’s final form owes much to the detailed criticism of two anonymous readers for the series. We are also grateful to colleagues who have answered queries or provided notes on drafts: David Rundle, James Willoughby, Richard Sharpe, Lynn Smith, Paul Trafford, and Elma Brenner. Our thanks also to Prior Philip, who has proven himself a patient and sympathetic companion.

When Prior Philip become the head of St Frideswide’s Priory (now Christ Church, Oxford) in the late 1170s, he was immediately tasked with completing a programme initiated by his predecessor, Robert of Cricklade, to grow the popular veneration of their patron. The devotion that had grown up around Thomas Becket after his assassination on 29 December 1170 was turning Canterbury into a major centre of pilgrimage. Robert himself was soon healed at the archbishop’s grave, opening his mind to the possibilities of such shrines. Philip orchestrated a translation of Frideswide’s relics into a new shrine on 12 February 1180, timed to coincide with a council held by King Henry II in Oxford. He quickly set about to promote the shrine as a centre of healing, as Robert probably envisioned. It was a messy business: pilgrims slept overnight in the church, splashed holy water, interrupted services, and vomited everywhere. Philip never complained openly about any of this, viewing the events as miracles.

As in the case of Thomas and other medieval saints, recording miracles was key to promoting a cult. Between 1180 and 1183, Philip began to write a rationale for miracles and document what happened to the pilgrims visiting his priory. The Miracles of St Frideswide is the result, a brilliant window into the struggles of everyday people whose stories were usually left untold. The only complete copy to survive is a manuscript from the shrine itself, as is the case for many similar miracle books, whose stories the canons read aloud. Philip himself oversaw its production. It is one of about eighty miracle collections produced in England during the vogue for the genre between the late eleventh to early thirteenth centuries.

div.head: Promoting St Frideswide
div.p:
Frideswide (or Frithuswith) was remembered in the twelfth century as an Anglo-Saxon princess who spurned an arranged marriage to become an abbess; the traditional date of her death is 727.
John Blair, ‘Frithuswith (d. 727), Abbess of Oxford’, in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, ed. H. C.G. Matthew and Brian Howard Harrison (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2004), https://doi.org/10.1093/ref:odnb/10183 relates the known details of Frideswide’s life. She was said to have founded a double monastery, housing both monks and nuns. Whatever its true origin, archaeological studies have confirmed that the site has roots going back to Anglo-Saxon times.
John Blair, Anglo-Saxon Oxfordshire (Stroud: Sutton, 1998), 62–63. It subsequently became a house of secular canons. Bishop Roger of Salisbury appears to have begun preparing for a new religious foundation there in 1111, and Augustinian canons from Holy Trinity, Aldgate moved in by 1120–22.
The traditional foundation date is 1122, but John Blair, ‘St Frideswide’s Monastery: Problems and Possibilities’, Oxoniensia 53 (1988): 227, https://oxoniensia.org/volumes/1988/blair2.pdf suggests an earlier date c. 1120; see also Edward J. Kealey, Roger of Salisbury, Viceroy of England (Berkeley: University of California Press, 1972), 121–22; J. C. Dickinson, The Origins of the Austin Canons and Their Introduction into England (London: SPCK, 1950), 113–14; Spencer Robert Wigram, ed., The Cartulary of the Monastery of St. Frideswide at Oxford, Oxford Historical Society 28, 31 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1895–1896), nos. 3–4; Gerald A. J. Hodgett, ed., The Cartulary of Holy Trinity Aldgate, Publications of the London Record Society 7 (Leicester: London Record Society, 1971), 2, 228. The Augustinian canons, also known as regular canons, were priests who lived together in a community according to a rule of life, typically concentrating on pastoral work or teaching locally. This mindset shaped St Frideswide’s Priory, which supported a number of writers in its early years alongside its shrine for healing.
Andrew N. J. Dunning, ‘St Frideswide’s Priory as a Centre of Learning in Early Oxford’, Mediaeval Studies 80 (2018): 253–96; for overviews of the shrine’s role in its community, see Henry Mayr-Harting, ‘Functions of a Twelfth-Century Shrine: The Miracles of St Frideswide’, in Studies in Medieval History Presented to R. H. C. Davis, ed. Henry Mayr-Harting and R. I. Moore (London: Hambledon Press, 1985), 193–206, https://doi.org/10.5040/9781472599131.ch-014; Benedicta Ward, ‘St Frideswide of Oxford’, in Benedictines in Oxford, ed. Henry Wansbrough and Anthony Marett-Crosby (London: Darton, Longman and Todd, 1997), 3–10, 278.

The priory community required some creativity to survive. It faced a serious material challenge to its existence when Roger of Salisbury died in 1139 without clearly transferring to the canons the rights to churches supposedly intended to support the priory.
Kealey, Roger of Salisbury, Viceroy of England, 121–23, 202–3, 245–46, 265–69. This resulted in a protracted legal dispute with Osney Abbey over the investiture of the church of St Mary Magdalen, coming to a head in 1147–51, 1173–76, and 1200, requiring papal intervention on each occasion.
H. E. Salter, ed., Cartulary of Oseney Abbey, Oxford Historical Society 89–91, 97, 98, 101 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1929–1936), nos. 780–94; Henry Richards Luard, ed., ‘Annales de Oseneia et Chronicon Thomæ Wykes’, in Annales monastici, vol. 4, Rerum Britannicarum medii aevi scriptores 36 (London: Longmans, Green, Reader, and Dyer, 1869), 25–27, 37–38, 50, https://archive.org/details/annalesmonastici04luar; Adrian Morey, Bartholomew of Exeter: Bishop and Canonist. A Study in the Twelfth Century (Cambridge: University Press, 1937), 56–59; C. R. Cheney, From Becket to Langton: English Church Government 1170–1213 (Manchester: University Press, 1956), 114; C. R. Cheney and Mary G. Cheney, The Letters of Pope Innocent III (1198–1216) Concerning England and Wales: A Calendar with an Appendix of Texts (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1967), no. 276; John Barron, ‘The Augustinian Canons and the University of Oxford: The Lost College of St George’, in The Church and Learning in Later Medieval Society: Essays in Honour of R. B. Dobson. Proceedings of the 1999 Harlaxton Symposium, ed. Caroline M. Barron and Jenny Stratford (Donington, Lincolnshire: Tyas, 2002), 238. The first prior, Master Wimund, had also resigned or died in 1138–39. The energetic Master Robert of Cricklade, a former teacher, was brought from Cirencester Abbey as his replacement, becoming prior from 1138×39 until 1174×79.
For the first date, see Robert of Cricklade, De connubio patriarche Iacob 3.3, discussed in Rodney M. Thomson and Michael Winterbottom, eds., William of Malmesbury: Miracles of the Blessed Virgin Mary (Woodbridge, Suffolk: Boydell Press, 2015), xv; later dates in David Knowles et al., eds., The Heads of Religious Houses: England and Wales (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2001–2008), 1:180, 284. He may have viewed the shrine of St Frideswide in part as a solution to the priory’s financial problems.

Robert was an active administrator, travelling to Paris and Rome in the 1140s to negotiate the priory’s rights.
Wigram, Cartulary of the Monastery of St. Frideswide, nos. 15–16, 1119–25; but no. 16 is a forgery according to Walther Holtzmann, Papsturkunden in England, Abhandlungen der Gesellschaft der Wissenschaften zu Göttingen. Philologisch-historische Klasse, n.s., 25, 3rd ser., 14, 33 (Berlin, 1930–1952), 3:164–5. He also initiated a programme of building works: archaeologists date a cloister to the 1140s, while the chancel of the priory church was probably begun in the 1160s but mostly constructed in the 1170s, with the transepts and nave following soon after.
Richard Halsey, ‘The 12th-Century Church of St. Frideswide’s Priory’, Oxoniensia 53 (1988): 120–21, 127–28, 133–35, 154–55, 157–58, https://oxoniensia.org/volumes/1988/halsey.pdf; Blair, ‘St Frideswide’s Monastery’, 237–39. Most fatefully for the future of the priory, Robert travelled to Rome on priory business via Sicily and Paris, gaining along the way the dedication to the translation of Phaedo by Aristippus and bringing back a Greek medical book to Eleanor of Aquitaine. Documents show that he was abroad from at least 1156 to 1158.
Charles Homer Haskins, ‘Further Notes on Sicilian Translations of the Twelfth Century’, Harvard Studies in Classical Philology 23 (1912): 162–64, https://doi.org/10.2307/310450; reprinted, ‘The Sicilian Translators of the Twelfth Century’, in Studies in the History of Mediaeval Science, 2nd ed., Harvard Historical Studies 27 (Cambridge, MA: Harvard University Press, 1927), 168–70; Elisabeth M. C. van Houts, ‘Les femmes dans le royaume Plantagenêt: Gendre, politique et nature’, in Plantagenêts et Capétiens: Confrontations et héritages, ed. Martin Aurell and Noël-Yves Tonnerre, Histoires de famille. La parenté au Moyen Âge 4 (Turnhout: Brepols, 2006), 100–102, https://doi.org/10.1484/m.hifa-eb.3.603. In Sicily, he contracted a disease that caused swelling in his left leg, perhaps elephantiasis, which recurred periodically until he made a pilgrimage to the grave of Thomas Becket.
Anne J. Duggan, ‘Thomas Is the Best Healer of the Virtuous Sick: The Medical Miracles of Thomas of Canterbury’, Transactions of the Medical Society of London 128 (2011–2012): 105; a window of Canterbury Cathedral was long taken to depict Robert, following the suggestion of Emily Williams, Notes on the Painted Glass of Canterbury Cathedral (Aberdeen: Aberdeen University Press, 1897), 31, https://archive.org/details/notesonpaintedgl00farrrich; but Rachel Koopmans, ‘Kentish Pilgrims in Canterbury Cathedral’s Miracle Windows’, Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes 80, no. 1 (2017): 10–12 shows that it better matches Benedict of Peterborough’s story of William of Dene. His enthusiastic letter to Benedict of Peterborough (died 1193) shows that the healing left a deep impression, which probably occurred in late 1171 or early 1172, twelve years or more after his trip to Sicily.
James Craigie Robertson, ed., ‘Miracula sancti Thomæ Cantuariensis, auctore Benedicto, abbate Petriburgensi’, in Materials for the History of Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, vol. 2, 7 vol., Rerum Britannicarum medii aevi scriptores 67 (London: Longman, 1875), 21–281, https://archive.org/details/materialsforhist02robe, chs 2.51–52; the letter also appears in an Old Norse version with an English translation, Eiríkr Magnússon, ed., Thómas saga erkibyskups: A Life of Archbishop Thomas Becket, in Icelandic, with English Translation, Notes and Glossary, trans. Eiríkr Magnússon, 2 vols, Rerum Britannicarum Medii Aevi Scriptores 65 (London: Longmans, 1875–1883), https://archive.org/details/thmassagaerkib02eir, ch. 111, which includes additional details in the following chapters that suggest the date of 1171–72, particularly the story of Eilward of Westoning, who was certainly at Canterbury into 1172, as Rachel Koopmans’ forthcoming translation of Benedict of Peterborough notes. The coincident intensification of building works in the 1170s, as well as the prominent rivalry with Canterbury in Philip’s Miracles, suggests that this perceived miracle was pivotal for the development of St Frideswide’s shrine.

Part of the canons’ rationale for bringing Robert to the priory was likely his learning.
Dunning, ‘St Frideswide’s Priory as a Centre of Learning in Early Oxford’, 258–70. He wrote a number of books both in Cirencester and his later years in Oxford.
Andrew N. J. Dunning, ‘Robert of Cricklade’, in Arlima: Archives de littérature du Moyen Âge, ed. Laurent Brun, 29 December 2017, https://arlima.net/no/1967 provides a bibliography of Robert’s works. He was also an active hagiographer. He wrote a Life and Miracles of Thomas Becket and likely a Life of Magnus, both of which only survive in Old Norse adaptations.
Margaret Orme, ‘A Reconstruction of Robert of Cricklade’s Vita et Miracula S. Thomae Cantuariensis’, Analecta Bollandiana 84 (1966): 379–98, https://doi.org/10.1484/j.abol.4.02618; Haki Antonsson, St. Magnús of Orkney: A Scandinavian Martyr-Cult in Context, Northern World 29 (Leiden: Brill, 2007), 42–67, 222, https://doi.org/10.1163/ej.9789004155800.i-272. As part of his efforts to raise the prominence of Frideswide, he also likely produced a Life of St Frideswide.

Robert pieced together information about the canons’ patron saint from what might have been limited sources.
Simon Yarrow, Saints and Their Communities: Miracle Stories in Twelfth-Century England, Oxford Historical Monographs (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2006), https://doi.org/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199283637.001.0001, ch. 6 considers the canons’ use of Frideswide alongside patterns at other houses. Almost no information survives about Frideswide from before the twelfth century. The earliest known accounts of her life are those of William de Malmesbury, in his Gesta pontificum;
Michael Winterbottom and Rodney M. Thomson, eds., William of Malmesbury: Gesta pontificum Anglorum/The History of the English Bishops, 2 vols, Oxford Medieval Texts (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2007), ch. 178. and Life A of Frideswide (BHL 3164), surviving in a single manuscript from the early twelfth century.
Edited in John Blair, ‘Saint Frideswide Reconsidered’, Oxoniensia 52 (1987): 93–101, https://oxoniensia.org/volumes/1987/blair.pdf; BHL numbers refer to the hagiographical index in Bibliotheca hagiographica latina antiquae et mediae aetatis, 2 vols, Subsidia hagiographica 6 (Brussels: Société des Bollandistes, 1898–1911) and its later supplements. This appears to have been compiled from several sources, with some apparent misunderstandings of the geography of Oxfordshire.
Blair, ‘Frideswide’, 83–85. The new life of Frideswide, Life B (BHL 3162), was certainly written by one of the canons before 1180, concluding with her still buried in the ground. It is anonymous in the manuscripts, but the author’s approach and style points to the prior.
Blair, 101–16 edits Life A; Blair, 80 discusses the attribution of Life B.
The work’s prologue addresses criticism of the earlier life of Frideswide as artless. The author asserts that it has a useful core that only needs a finishing touch and a little more research:

quote.p:
My most dear brethren, I have taken care to bring together everything into one volume on the life and virtues of the most blessed virgin Frideswide, worthy of every veneration, which I have been able to learn from the chronicles, as well as in certain volumes of true histories or in catalogues of the saints of England. It appears clearly that he has avoided error in many things, whoever the writer was of the life of that most holy virgin – although some in their pride think little of him. Dismissing a pen led in simplicity, they approve of a flower that cares more for its appearance than the usefulness of its fruit.
Robert of Cricklade, Vita sancte Frideswide uirginis, prologue, edited in Blair, 103:
De uita et uirtutibus beatissime et omni ueneratione dignissime uirginis Frideswide, fratres karissimi, que addiscere potui in chronicis, et preter hec in quibusdam autenticarum hystoriarum uoluminibus siue in cathalogis sanctorum Anglie, in unum cohartare uolumen curaui. Vbi liquido apparet quia longe ab errore in pluribus declinauit, quisquis ille fuit uite uirginis sacratissime scriptor, licet quorumdam supercilio contempnendus uideatur, qui stili simplicitate in improbandum adducti fastidium, florum probant se magis attendere speciem, quam fructus utilitatem.

div.p:
This also fits with Robert’s mindset: his written work can be summarized as an attempt to make materials from the past more accessible to present-day readers. Similar sentiments can be seen in the prologue to his Anthology of Pliny’s Natural History.
Bodo Näf, ed., Roberti Crikeladensis Defloratio naturalis historie Plinii secundi, Lateinische Sprache und Literatur des Mittelalters 36 (Bern: Lang, 2002), 1–3.

Robert’s work makes Frideswide into an even more marvellous and learned figure. While Life A gives her six or seven months to learn the Psalter, Robert reduces this to five months and emphasizes the extent of the improvement this wrought on her character, reflecting the highest ideals for learning.
Blair, ‘Frideswide’, 32, 96, 103. He specifically elevates Frideswide beyond the capacities of any male child.
Blair, 75, 104. He makes the saint almost inhuman in her perfection.
Anne B. Thompson, ‘Shaping a Saint’s Life: Frideswide of Oxford’, Medium Ævum 63, no. 1 (1994): 34–52, https://doi.org/10.2307/43629614 compares Robert’s work with the South English Legendary; revised in Anne B. Thompson, Everyday Saints and the Art of Narrative in the South English Legendary (Aldershot, Hampshire: Ashgate, 2003), 142–53. He designed the book to bring the saint into the priory’s liturgical life, structuring it as thirteen short chapters that can be read independently.
List of headings in Blair, ‘Frideswide’, 102: although the editor does not state this, these correspond to the thirteen paragraphs in the edited text, which reflect the sections found in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Laud misc. 114, fols 132r–140r. The clear implication of Robert’s Life is that the priory’s patron deserved veneration.

Before anyone could engage in building a shrine or orchestrating a memorable translation, the first objective of anyone wishing to develop a saint’s cult was to find relics. In the Romsey Legendary, which includes excerpts from Robert’s Life of Frideswide and Philip’s Miracles (discussed in more detail below), there is an undated account of the invention of St Frideswide’s relics, later celebrated on 15 May. This might have occurred before Robert’s priorate, but it was likely during his time there. It explains that the canons were concerned that the Benedictine monks of Abingdon Abbey, which held the house between the departure of the secular canons and the arrival of the Augustinians, may have stolen the body:

quote.p: But the blessed virgin Frideswide, bright in miracles, lay in the same place where she was buried – that is in the church dedicated to her honour, and to the honour of the Holy Trinity, of the Blessed Virgin Mary, and of all saints – for nearly 480 years. In the space of this time there were different arrangements of that monastery. For as time passed, after the monks left that place, secular clergy occupied the monastery with its possessions. After they were cast out because of their extravagance, the monks of Abingdon held it for some time. Finally, however, the regular canons, religious men, were brought in, mostly recovering it, and they live there even today. After they arrived at the monastery, they feared that the aforementioned monks had carried off the virgin’s body from its tomb. Having proclaimed a three-day fast, they secretly excavated the tomb during the night with a large amount of light. They found the stone coffin empty. Since they were almost without hope from the beginning, they had intended to stop, but on the advice of a prudent man among them, they tried to dig deeper. He was saying that sometimes it was the custom to place empty coffins over the bodies of saints, so that if thieves came and wished to steal the body, they would go away frustrated. Therefore, they dug earnestly, and came to the virgin’s body. When this happened, all their lights were suddenly put out. Thus the omnipotent Lord mercifully drove out all doubt from the hearts of those who were thinking that they had not found the body of the virgin but of someone else, amazed by the visible miracle. For all the lights that had been put out earlier were relit by a fire coming down from God. When they had seen the miracle, they were filled with great joy and praised the Lord together. Having been assured of the truth, they left the most glorious one’s body in peace in the same place.

Thereafter, miracles began to occur more often than usual, and the virgin’s tomb was visited by people from many parts. Among these, after many different revelations were shown on this, and countless visible miracles had gone before, it was ordered with the agreement of the king – that is, Henry II, who reigned at that time and who appeared in his palace outside Oxford – that the people should lift up the virgin’s body from the earth and move it to a more prominent place. Therefore, at the prayers and insistence of Philip, then prior, and of the entire monastery …
Romsey Legendary, Frideswide, chs 5–6, London, British Library, Lansdowne MS 436, fols 103ra–103va, discussed in Blair, 116–18:
Iacuit autem beata uirgo Frideswida miraculis clara in eodem quo sepulta fuit loco. uidelicet in ecclesia sua in honore sancte Trinitatis beate uirginis Marie et omnium sanctorum dedicata ferme quadringentis octoginta annis. In cuius temporis spacio uarii fuerunt illius monasterii status. Nam processu temporis monialibus de loco illo recedentibus monasterium cum possessionibus optinuerunt clerici seculares. Quibus ob eorum insolentiam exclusis monachi Abyndonienses per aliquot tempora |133rb| omnia habuerunt. Finaliter uero canonici regulares uiri religiosi illuc introducti pro maiori parte omnia recuperantes usque hodie ibidem inhabitant. Qui post eorum aduentum ad dictum monasterium hesitantes an monachi predicti corpus uirginis a sepulture sue loco abstulissent⸵ indicto triduano ieiunio secrete de nocte cum lumine copioso sepulchrum effodientes sarcofagum lapideum uacuum inuenerunt. Et cum iam quasi desperantes ab inceptis desistere proposuissent⸵ cuiusdam discreti inter illos usi consilio profundius fodere conati sunt. Dicebat autem quod quandoque sic fieri consueuit. super sanctorum corpora poni sarcofaga uacua ut fures si forte uenirent et corpus furari uellent⸵ sic delusi recederent. Diligenter igitur fodientes. ad corpus uirginis peruenerunt⸵ quod cum fieret omnia luminaria que habebant subito extincta sunt. Vnde illi admirantes cum non corpus uirginis sed alicuius alterius se inuenisse putarent⸵ omnem dubietatem a cordibus eorum euidenti miraculo. omnipotens dominus misericorditer effugauit. Nam omnia luminaria prius extincta igne de superueniente diuinitus sunt reaccensa quod cum uidissent miraculum repleti gaudio magno dominum collau\da/bant. Cercioresque de ueritate affecti⸵ corpus glorio⟨sis⟩simi in eodem loco in pace dimiserunt.
|133va| Ceperunt autem extunc crebrius solito ibidem miracula fieri et a populis diuersarum parcium sepulchrum uirginis deuocius uisitari. Inter hec multis reuelacionibus diuersis super hoc preostensis⸵ innumeris eciam precedentibus miraculis euidentibus decretum est unanimi assensu regis uidelicet Henrici secundi illo tempore regnantis et in palacio suo extra Oxoniam tunc existentis cleri eciam et populi uirginis corpus e terra eleuari⸵ et in locum eminenciorem debere transferri. Ad preces igitur et instanciam Philippi tunc prioris et tocius conuentus …

div.p:
Following this, the compiler begins to excerpt Philip’s Miracles (ch. 1). This passage gives a sense of the canons’ mindset leading up to the translation of 1180: they were confident that they possessed the relics of a true saint, that God would perform miracles through Frideswide’s intercession, and that they were supported in this by popular sentiment. The Augustinians had already successfully established centres with a medical focus, most famously St Bartholomew’s in Smithfield, London, or likely Norton Priory in Cheshire, where archaeologists have uncovered an unusually large number of skeletons with signs of Paget’s disease.
J. Patrick Greene, Norton Priory: The Archaeology of a Medieval Religious House (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1989), 7. By the end of the 1170s, therefore, the priory had a ready shrine, with a newly expanded church, identified relics, and a readable saint’s life. It only remained to conduct a translation ceremony for Frideswide, as a number of shrines did in the Norman period, to advertise it to pilgrims.

div.head: The translation of St Frideswide
div.p:
Robert of Cricklade’s successor as prior, Philip, presumably took up the office in 1178 or 1179. Few details about him have survived: it is not even clear how people referred to him before he became prior. Medieval documents consistently name him Prior Philip of St Frideswide or Prior Philip of Oxford; modern scholars often call him Philip of Oxford.
Richard Sharpe, A Handlist of the Latin Writers of Great Britain and Ireland Before 1540, Publications of the Journal of Medieval Latin 1 (Turnhout: Brepols, 1997), no. 1212 provides this appellation; Thomas Tanner, Bibliotheca Britannico-Hibernica, ed. David Wilkins (London: Bowyer, 1748), 596, refers to him as ‘Philippus de S. Fridiswida’. What is certain is that Philip arranged for an elaborate translation of Frideswide’s relics on 12 February 1180, and was an enthusiastic supporter of the shrine, completing the first phase of his Miracles of St Frideswide between 1180 and 1183.

The prologue to the Miracles shows that the author was well read, and one might expect to find him in a document as Master Philip, but this name was common, and no candidate in documentary sources can be proven to represent the prior earlier in life. Master Philip of Calne has the sort of background that one might expect of the prior: a Londoner who studied theology at Tours and was a member of the household of Thomas Becket, teaching canon law at Rheims when the archbishop went into exile. He was known to both John of Salisbury and Peter the Chanter.
Anne J. Duggan, The Correspondence of Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, 1162–1170, Oxford Medieval Texts (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2000), 231n1. His fate is unknown after he was restored to royal favour in 1166. William fitz Stephen describes him as having been in ill health on this occasion, writing years later in 1173×74, which probably implies that Master Philip did not succumb to the illness.
James Craigie Robertson, ed., ‘Vita sancti Thomæ, Cantuariensis archiepiscopi et martyris, auctore Willelmo filio Stephani’, in Materials for the History of Thomas Becket, Archbishop of Canterbury, vol. 3, Rerum Britannicarum medii aevi scriptores 67 (London: Longman, 1877), 101, http://archive.org/details/materialsforhist03robe. This educational background and a personal connection to Thomas Becket are intriguing possibilities, but there is nothing to link Philip of Calne and Prior Philip. A Master Philip given the title of canon witnesses at least two documents from 1174×76, interestingly alongside John of Salisbury, but he is likely identical to a Philip who was a secular rather than a regular canon, based at the collegiate church of All Saints in Derby.
M. J. Franklin, ed., Winchester 1070–1204, English Episcopal Acta 8 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1993), nos. 140, 141, 166, 176. There is also a vice-archdeacon of Oxford recorded as Master Philip in 1174, but this figure is certainly not a canon of St Frideswide’s, since he was tasked with putting the canons of Osney Abbey into possession of the church of St Mary Magdalen in Oxford over St Frideswide’s.
C. R. Cheney and Bridgett E. A. Jones, Canterbury 1162–1190, English Episcopal Acta 2 (London: Oxford University Press, 1986), no. 178; Salter, Cartulary of Oseney Abbey, no. 784. While these examples do not shed any definite light on Prior Philip’s past, they illustrate some of the paths that a cleric in his position might have taken.

Records for St Frideswide’s are poor, and as with Robert of Cricklade, the exact dates of Philip’s priorate are unknown. He judged cases involving tithes on behalf of the bishop of Lincoln in 1183–88.
H. E. Salter, ed., Eynsham Cartulary, Oxford Historical Society 49, 51 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1907), nos. 62, 158; discussed in White Kennett, Parochial Antiquities Attempted in the History of Ambrosden, Burcester and Other Adjacent Parts in the Counties of Oxford and Bucks (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1818), 1:200–203; Salter, Cartulary of Oseney Abbey, no. 853. He also appears in several charters of the nearby Godstow Abbey, witnessing several transactions and resolving disputes for this community of Benedictine nuns.
Emilie Amt, ed., The Latin Cartulary of Godstow Abbey, Records of Social and Economic History, n.s., 52 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2014), nos. 29, 231, 492, 597, 619; David M. Smith, Lincoln 1067–1185, English Episcopal Acta 1 (London: Oxford University Press, 1980), no. 305. After appearing in several documents from 1189–91, he is last recorded in a charter of 4 July 1191.
Salter, Cartulary of Oseney Abbey, no. 63B, with Philip also appearing in nos. 48, 63A–C, 335B, 510, 853; Wigram, Cartulary of the Monastery of St. Frideswide, nos. 873, 1188; Agnes M. Leys, ed., The Sandford Cartulary, Oxfordshire Record Society 19, 22 (Oxford: Oxfordshire Record Society, 1938), no. 128; H. E. Salter, ed., The Thame Cartulary, Oxfordshire Record Society 25, 26 (Oxford: Oxfordshire Record Society, 1947), no. 191; Franklin, Winchester 1070–1204, no. 154. He is not known to have written anything other than the Miracles.
Robert Easting, ed., The Revelation of the Monk of Eynsham, Early English Text Society 318 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2002), 211–12 notes a possibility that the prior in this text is Philip, but considers it more likely to be Bartholomew, prior of Eynsham. His successor, Simon, was first recorded in a document of 27 November 1195.
Knowles et al., Heads of Religious Houses, 1:180, 284.

St Frideswide’s shrine was an inherited project that Philip was at first in no hurry to complete, as he describes the situation. He might have planned to wait for construction on the church to be completed before arranging the ceremony. While Philip was away on business in London during his first year in office, Frideswide herself appeared in a dream to the prior’s assistant, Robert, who was also a relative (ch. 4). She demanded to know why Philip was absent. When the prior finally arrived in the dream, she rebuked him for the delay and requested a swift translation. The story implies that the canons made the translation a matter of urgency immediately after this dream, suggesting that Philip’s priorate began in 1178 or 1179.

The translation took place on 12 February 1180, timed to coincide with a council organized by Henry II.
This council introduced a new coinage: Martin Allen, Mints and Money in Medieval England (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2012), 49–52, https://doi.org/10.1017/cbo9781139057394; Gilbert Stack, ‘A Lost Law of Henry II: The Assize of Oxford and Monetary Reform’, Haskins Society Journal 16 (2005): 96–97. This allowed Philip to list many important officials present at the ceremony (ch. 1). Richard of Dover, the archbishop of Canterbury, moved the saint’s relics into a new shrine. The text technically describes it as a movable feretory (feretrum) that could be carried in processions. The exact location in which it was displayed is not known, but historians conjecture that it was raised directly above the empty tomb.
On the relationship between the grave and shrine, see Blair, ‘St Frideswide’s Monastery’, 248–51; John Crook, English Medieval Shrines, Boydell Studies in Medieval Art and Architecture (Woodbridge, Suffolk: Boydell Press, 2011), 209–12. Pilgrims would pray around and even on top of the grave, arrange for the feretory to pass over them in a procession, and spend nights on end before it. Maintaining both a tomb and a shrine was perhaps another nod to Canterbury, which similarly maintained the site of Thomas Becket’s original burial after his translation.
John Jenkins, ‘Replication or Rivalry? The “Becketization” of Pilgrimage in English Cathedrals’, Religion 49, no. 1 (2 January 2019): 38, https://doi.org/10.1080/0048721x.2018.1515327.

figure.head: Seal of St Frideswide’s, 1180s (✠ sigillvm: ecclesie sancte frideswide oxenefordie:), from the frontispiece to Wigram’s edition of the cartulary

div.p:
Indicative of Philip’s high aspirations for the shrine is the new seal for St Frideswide’s made towards the end of the 1180s. Frideswide holds a fleur-de-lis in her right hand, and what has been described as an open book in her left hand, but appears more specifically to be a set of wax tablets.
Composite drawing from London, British Library, Seal LXX.79 in T. A. Heslop, ‘The Late 12th-Century Seal of St. Frideswide’s Priory’, Oxoniensia 53 (1988): 272, https://oxoniensia.org/volumes/1988/stfrideswidenotes.pdf; reproduced from four Oxford charters in Wigram, Cartulary of the Monastery of St. Frideswide, 1:ii; Anthony Wood, ‘Survey of the Antiquities of the City of Oxford,’ Composed in 1661–6, ed. Andrew Clark, Oxford Historical Society 15, 17, 37 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1889–1899), 2:159 describes it as a picture of a doctor with a kind of cope. She appears in a similar pose in a surviving thirteenth-century boss in the roof of the chapter house.
An Inventory of the Historical Monuments in the City of Oxford (London: His Majesty’s Stationery Office, 1939), plate 107. Most audaciously, the canopy is reminiscent of that found in the bulls of the masters of the Order of St John of Jerusalem, comparing Frideswide’s shrine with the tomb of Christ itself.
Heslop, ‘Seal of St. Frideswide’s Priory’, 271–74; Blair, ‘St Frideswide’s Monastery’, 256.

div.head: Prior Philip’s Miracles
div.p:
A shrine in the twelfth century aiming to become a destination for pilgrimage needed a miracle collection. Many such centres would keep a registry of the miracles that occurred under their auspices, sometimes as a simple list. The earliest surviving literary miracle books date to the fifth century, and such collections were in vogue in England between about 1080 and 1220.
Rachel Koopmans, Wonderful to Relate: Miracle Stories and Miracle Collecting in High Medieval England, The Middle Ages Series (Philadelphia: University of Pennsylvania Press, 2011), https://doi.org/10.9783/9780812206999 surveys English miracle collecting; Simon Yarrow, ‘Narrative, Audience and the Negotiation of Community in Twelfth-Century English Miracle Collections’, Studies in Church History 42 (2006): 65–77, https://doi.org/10.1017/s0424208400003843 provides an overview of the genre with reference to Philip’s work. These were often written as they occurred or soon afterwards, and in many cases there seems to have been a designated registrar with the duty of judging the validity of miracles and recording them.
Robert Bartlett, Why Can the Dead Do Such Great Things? Saints and Worshippers from the Martyrs to the Reformation (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Press, 2013), 558–70 introduces the methodological issues surrounding miracle books; Ronald C. Finucane, ‘The Use and Abuse of Medieval Miracles’, History 60, no. 198 (February 1975): 4–6, https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1468-229x.1975.tb02025.x summarizes shrines’ practices. Some miracle books are highly stereotyped, and Philip does not shy from embellishing his accounts with biblical and liturgical references, but this does not detract from his collection’s immediacy. The handful of datable miracles occur in chronological order, and most of the collection probably occurs roughly in the order that Philip heard them, though some are grouped by location or his source. The prior documents the miracles thoroughly to establish their veracity, typically providing the full name of the miracle’s recipient as well as the locality from which the person came. Most of these people do not appear in any other written source, and hagiography is often cited as one of the best genres in medieval literature for understanding the circumstances of everyday life, though readers need to take the context and motives for their composition into account.
Richard Sharpe, ‘Latin in Everyday Life’, in Medieval Latin: An Introduction and Bibliographical Guide, ed. F. A. C. Mantello and A. G. Rigg (Washington, DC: Catholic University of America Press, 1996), 318–19 situates the Frideswide text among other examples of Latin representing ordinary people.

At least the first part of Philip’s text as it now stands in the manuscript was written between June 1180 and June 1183. It is datable through references to Roger, the abbot of Abingdon, who died in 1185 (ch. 42) and John the Scot, bishop-elect of St Andrews (ch. 1). According to Philip, John was present at the translation along with Alexis, the papal legate to Scotland. The Augustinian canons of St Andrews Cathedral Priory had elected John in 1178, but the king instead had his chaplain Hugh consecrated. After papal intervention, John was consecrated at Holyrood Abbey on 15 June 1180, but after a protracted conflict, both John and Hugh resigned at Rome in June 1183. John made another attempt at reviving the case between 1186 and the beginning of 1188, but eventually capitulated.
D. E. R. Watt, Medieval Church Councils in Scotland (Edinburgh: T&T Clark, 2000), 25–29; A. A. M. Duncan, Scotland: The Making of the Kingdom, The Edinburgh History of Scotland 1 (Edinburgh: Oliver & Boyd, 1975), 270–77. Philip’s account of the translation (ch. 1) directly reflects this dispute. It originally referred to master John, then elect, and afterwards bishop, of St Andrews (magistro Iohanne tunc quidem electo. postmodum autem episcopo sancti Andree, fol. 2ra). Later, the phrase and afterwards bishop (postmodum autem episcopo) was erased, since in retrospect John was not considered to have been bishop. This dating can only strictly be applied to the earliest part of the text, consisting of the prologue through chapter 43, filling most of the manuscript’s first two quires (fols 1–16); the scribe of fol. 16v had some difficulties controlling the pen at the end of the page, possibly indicating that he was then writing in a book that had already been bound. Nonetheless, since the miracles are still news to many pilgrims even towards the end of the text – Margaret of Collingbourne (ch. 73) does not even know how to follow the instructions that Frideswide gives her in a dream – all the events Philip describes probably occurred in the early 1180s.

Philip’s Miracles are both a record and a text for spiritual edification, certainly among his priory and perhaps also for the laity.
Scholars continue to debate the audiences of miracle collections: D. W. Rollason, Saints and Relics in Anglo-Saxon England (Oxford: Blackwell, 1989), 95–104 makes a case for interpreting the target audience of hagiography through the people it depicts; following this, Anne E. Bailey, ‘“The Rich and the Poor, the Lesser and the Great”: Social Representations of Female Pilgrims in Medieval England’, Cultural and Social History 11, no. 1 (March 2014): 9–29, https://doi.org/10.2752/147800414x13802176314401 approaches the Frideswide collection and others as being intended for popular dissemination. The book opens with a high-flown prologue that sets out his rationale for writing in theological terms, narrowing down from the purpose of posthumous miracles to those of the virgin of which he writes; these occur primarily, he says, to strengthen faith. He largely follows the works of Augustine, whose ideas were widely known, and specifically his notion that creation is the one true miracle, the resurrection of Christ bettering this through re-creation.
For summaries of Western approaches to miracles in this period, see Bartlett, Saints and Worshippers from the Martyrs to the Reformation, ch. 9; Benedicta Ward, ‘Miracles in the Middle Ages’, in The Cambridge Companion to Miracles, ed. Graham H. Twelftree (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2011), 149–64, https://doi.org/10.1017/CCOL9780521899864.009; Benedicta Ward, Miracles and the Medieval Mind: Theory, Record and Event, 1000–1215, 2nd ed. (Aldershot, Hampshire: Scolar Press, 1987), chs 1–2. Trends in philosophy also influenced him, and the prologue refers specifically to the Aristotelian concepts of privation (priuatio/στέρησις) and possession (habitus/ἕξις), the first in British writing, to communicate the transformation that the miracles accomplish.
Cf. D. A. Callus and R. W. Hunt, eds., John Blund: Treatise on the Soul, trans. Michael Dunne, 2nd ed., Auctores Britannici Medii Aevi 2 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2012), ch. 10.129–131; Rodney M. Thomson, ed., Alexander Nequam: Speculum speculationum, Auctores Britannici Medii Aevi 11 (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 1988), chap. 2.59.5. For Philip and his contemporaries, what is most marvellous about these divine occurrences, and the reason for recording them, is their evangelistic ability to transform disbelief into belief.
Robert Easting and Richard Sharpe, eds., Peter of Cornwall’s Book of Revelations, British Writers of the Middle Ages and the Early Modern Period 5 (Toronto: Pontifical Institute of Mediaeval Studies, 2013), 68 notes other examples. In this context, Philip views it as a sin not to share these stories far and wide, a point that he continues to emphasize later in the text. He often depicts pilgrims as making their journey to St Frideswide as a direct response to hearing of her miracles (as in chs 34, 60).

While Philip views cures as having taken place by the divine hand, he participates in a strain of thought that sought to understand miracles within the bounds of nature’s activities.
Ward, Miracles and the Medieval Mind, 4–9. Although the collection describes phenomena that medieval writers often classify as demonic possession, Philip instead presents these cases as madness (chs 22, 61, 83, 97, 103), with only one hint of external evil influence (ch. 28). In this, he follows a pattern of writers in the mid-twelfth century increasingly looking for medical explanations for such behaviour.
Anne E. Bailey, ‘Miracles and Madness: Dispelling Demons in Twelfth-Century Hagiography’, in Demons and Illness from Antiquity to the Early-Modern Period, ed. Siam Bhayro and Catherine Rider, Magical and Religious Literature of Late Antiquity 5 (Leiden: Brill, 2017), 241–44, https://doi.org/10.1163/9789004338548_014. He is acutely aware that mental health can have both physical causes and results (e.g. chs 85, 105). He only occasionally uses the opportunity to moralize, as in the case of a lustful and notably anonymous pilgrim (ch. 43, part of which was later expurgated in the manuscript). His approach to pilgrims is otherwise non-judgemental: he does not use Emmeline of Eddington’s suicide attempt, the trauma of which results in her becoming unable to speak, as an opportunity for preaching, and indeed she is given a permanent place in the community (ch. 28). The collection is spiritual, but Philip is not necessarily spiritualizing in his assessment of symptoms.

The prior presents the church of St Frideswide itself as a communal space, used in ways that might seem unconventional to modern readers.
James Bugslag, ‘Performative Thaumaturgy: The State of Research on Curative and Spiritual Interaction at Medieval Pilgrimage Shrines’, in The Sacred and the Secular in Medieval Healing: Sites, Objects, and Texts, ed. Barbara S. Bowers and Linda Migl Keyser, AVISTA Studies in the History of Medieval Technology, Science and Art 10 (London: Routledge, 2016), 219–65, https://doi.org/10.4324/9781315085296-10 summarizes pilgrims’ uses of shrines in Western Europe. The daily liturgical life of the church is certainly important, and patients are often healed through interacting with it, notably at matins (chs 31, 59), a Mass (chs 6, 22, 34, 35, 40, 41, 42), or vespers (chs 21, 42). At one point, Frideswide even speaks in the words of the liturgy (ch. 38). In spite of this, the atmosphere often comes across as something closer to an emergency department than a sanctuary. Pilgrims, ranging from beggars to the prior himself, sleep at the church for days on end.
This occurs in chapters 7, 10, 14, 24, 28, 34, 42, 59, 63, 67, 69, 73, 75, 78, 81, and 102. Emma of Pyrton stays there for almost three weeks (ch. 63). This was a common practice throughout the classical and medieval worlds: modern scholars refer to the phenomenon as an incubation cult.
See, for example, Fritz Graf, ‘Dangerous Dreaming: The Christian Transformation of Dream Incubation’, Archiv für Religionsgeschichte 15, no. 1 (2014): 117–42, https://doi.org/10.1515/arege-2013-0009; David Knipp, ‘The Chapel of Physicians at Santa Maria Antiqua’, Dumbarton Oaks Papers 56 (2002): 1–23, https://doi.org/10.2307/1291851. This was not merely a matter of one or two people sleeping overnight at a time in front of the shrine, but often a gathering of people, as the scene appears in one pilgrim’s dream (ch. 73).

There is a strong sense of a common cause in bringing about healing, often requiring creative solutions, such as having a woman who could not walk carried into the church (ch. 96), or a canon throwing a bucket of holy water into the face of a madman who was driving people from the building (ch. 22). The description of pilgrims as somewhat disruptive to the church, without complaint among the clergy, is a common feature of miracle collections. Vomiting, for example, is a positive sign that someone has been cured, and not an occasion to complain about the expense of cleaning up (chs 32, 39, 49, 62, 63, 64, 85, 86, 100). Some scholars have tended to interpret this welcome disarrangement as leniency borne of the offerings that pilgrims brought.
Pierre-André Sigal, ‘Reliques, pèlerinages et miracles dans l’Église médiévale (XIe–XIIIe siècle)’, Revue d’histoire de l’Église de France 76, no. 197 (1990): 193–211, https://doi.org/10.3406/rhef.1990.3494. If this was the motivation, it is one that Philip did not state openly: the only mention of a monetary offering in the collection notes it as a ritual action at home for someone unable to travel (ch. 60). Many shrines were no doubt profitable operations, but the canons present their motivations as more akin to opening a hospital than a tourist destination.

This unstructured atmosphere is a common way to present pilgrimage sites. The twentieth-century anthropologists Victor and Edith Turner called it communitas, an equalizing tendency that could temporarily erase social structures. A number of scholars have challenged this as broadly applicable model, but it reflects something of what Philip hoped to convey.
Victor W. Turner, The Ritual Process: Structure and Anti-Structure, The Lewis Henry Morgan Lectures 1966 (Chicago: Aldine, 1969), https://doi.org/10.4324/9781315134666, ch. 4; Victor W. Turner and Edith L. B. Turner, Image and Pilgrimage in Christian Culture: Anthropological Perspectives, Lectures on the History of Religions, n.s., 11 (New York: Columbia University Press, 1978), 134–37, 250–55; Anne E. Bailey, ‘Modern and Medieval Approaches to Pilgrimage, Gender and Sacred Space’, History and Anthropology 24, no. 4 (December 2013): 493–512, https://doi.org/10.1080/02757206.2013.813850 is a review of more recent anthropological approaches with reference to Frideswide. The function of this in Philip’s work is in part to emphasize its evangelistic aspects, which makes the crowd is an essential element in nearly every story: they are the witnesses that both authenticate and spread the miracles. Henry Mayr-Harting describes it as a ritual therapy which brought St Frideswide, the sufferer and the crowd, in a three-cornered relationship, face to face with each other. The power of this therapy lay not only in its effect on the sufferer, but also in its effect on the crowd, and thence again, through their acceptance of the sufferer, on the sufferer himself or herself.
Mayr-Harting, ‘Functions of a Twelfth-Century Shrine’, 205. This forms the basic pattern of Philip’s miracle stories: symptoms, healing following prayer, and finally proclamation to or witnessing by the crowd, which usually breaks out into praise of God.

div.head: Pilgrim demographics
div.p: Depending on how one counts, there are at least 135 identifiable individuals – 52 male, 83 female – who visit the shrine in Philip’s Miracles. Of these, 18 are companions rather than the sick, usually children’s parents, but this figure does not take into account the unnumbered groups of friends who assist pilgrims, and Philip does not always say when children are accompanied by their parents. The numbers of his pilgrims and their symptoms have fascinated readers as far back as the fourteenth-century excerpter who created the Romsey Legendary, discussed below, who assembled a partial list of the diseases ailing Frideswide’s pilgrims.

The travellers came from within an average radius of 56 km from Oxford (median 39 km). Those from further afield often have another reason to be there. William of Wales was on the way to the Holy Sepulchre (ch. 7); Haimo de Saint-Cyr, a knight from Brittany, was visiting a relative (ch. 9); a young man from Gloucester was on the way to Santiago de Compostela, and nearly cancels his pilgrimage after his purse is stolen, returned only through divine intervention (ch. 44).

figure.head: Origins of the pilgrims to Frideswide

div.p:
Some of the first modern attempts to use miracle collections for social history approached them statistically.
Ronald C. Finucane, Miracles and Pilgrims: Popular Beliefs in Medieval England (London: Dent, 1977), 11, 44, 66, 127–29, 169 addresses the Frideswide collection. Historians have used the stories to discuss the role of groups that are otherwise poorly represented in sources, particularly women,
Mayr-Harting, ‘Functions of a Twelfth-Century Shrine’ was the first to bring attention to the Frideswide collection in this respect; see more recently Anne E. Bailey, ‘Flights of Distance, Time and Fancy: Women Pilgrims and Their Journeys in English Medieval Miracle Narratives’, Gender & History 24, no. 2 (August 2012): 292–309, https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1468-0424.2012.01683.x; Anne E. Bailey, ‘Wives, Mothers and Widows on Pilgrimage: Categories of “Woman” Recorded at English Healing Shrines in the High Middle Ages’, Journal of Medieval History 39, no. 2 (June 2013): 197–219, https://doi.org/10.1080/03044181.2013.769117; Anne E. Bailey, ‘Women Pilgrims and Their Travelling Companions in Twelfth-Century England’, Viator 46, no. 1 (January 2015): 115–34, https://doi.org/10.1484/j.viator.5.103503. children,
Ronald C. Finucane, The Rescue of the Innocents: Endangered Children in Medieval Miracles (New York: St. Martin’s Press, 1997), 37–38, 59–60, 64–65; Anne E. Bailey, ‘Miracle Children: Medieval Hagiography and Childhood Imperfection’, Journal of Interdisciplinary History 47, no. 3 (Winter 2017): 267–85, https://doi.org/10.1162/jinh_a_01012. and the disabled.
Louise E. Wilson, ‘Hagiographical Interpretations of Disability in the Twelfth-Century Miracula of St Frideswide of Oxford’, in The Treatment of Disabled Persons in Medieval Europe: Examining Disability in the Historical, Legal, Literary, Medical, and Religious Discourses of the Middle Ages, ed. Wendy J. Turner and Tory Vandeventer Pearman (Lewiston, NY: Edwin Mellen Press, 2010), 135–66. Women make up 76 of 117 pilgrims, excluding companions, who are specifically mentioned (65 per cent). The text cannot be taken as a random sample: if it were, one would expect, for example, a greater number of cases involving complications surrounding childbirth (chs 19, 32, 33, 35, 38), unusual for miracle collections but not without parallel.
Hilary Powell, ‘The “Miracle of Childbirth”: The Portrayal of Parturient Women in Medieval Miracle Narratives’, Social History of Medicine 25, no. 4 (October 2012): 796–97, https://doi.org/10.1093/shm/hks019. Researchers have become more cautious over time in using miracle collections to make statements about their subjects: for example, historians in the mid-twentieth century tended to interpret the weeping and lamentations of women at shrines as indicating that they found the experience emotionally overwhelming, whereas they are now more likely to call this a literary topos.
Anne E. Bailey, ‘Lamentation Motifs in Medieval Hagiography’, in Sex, Gender, and the Sacred: Reconfiguring Religion in Gender History, ed. Joanna de Groot and Sue Morgan (Chichester, West Sussex: Wiley-Blackwell, 2014), 135–49, https://doi.org/10.1002/9781118833926.ch7.

Determining pilgrims’ age as well as their social status is often difficult, but there appear to be around 26 minors (18 girls, 8 boys) represented in the collection. Children are usually, but not always, accompanied by their parents: among the travelling companions, the text mentions 11 men and 7 women specifically, it presumably being easier for fathers to travel. In many cases both parents come and go with their child, but things do not always go so smoothly. Sometimes the parents lose patience: the blind Agnes of Duns Tew is abandoned by her father (ch. 56), while the mother of Emmeline of Eddington is anxious to leave after staying at the shrine for four to five days (ch. 28). In some cases parents made the pilgrimage on behalf of their sick children, such as the father from Leicestershire (ch. 60). Ediva, though blind, brought the ten-year-old Henry some 45 km with her from Wanborough: there is no mention of a guide, as in many other cases of blindness (ch. 67). While the more fortunate among the infirm come in a cart (chs 34, 73, 81, 96), the parents of seventeen-year-old Matilda of Northampton had abandoned her after she went blind, and she made her own way to the shrine, around 70 km, as a beggar (ch. 42). Philip’s collection leaves no doubt that life was difficult for anyone in these situations.

There is little information about pilgrimage to St Frideswide after Philip finished his collection, in part because so many records have been lost, but also because miracle collections such as Philip’s went out of fashion after the early thirteenth century. Another translation was held for Frideswide in 1289, when the priory created a more ornate shrine, of which fragments can still be seen at Christ Church.
Crook, English Medieval Shrines, 248–52. Catherine of Aragon visited the shrine in 1518 during her final pregnancy.
J. R.L. Highfield, ‘Catherine of Aragon’s Visit to the Shrine of St. Frideswide’, Oxoniensia 53 (1988): 274–75, https://oxoniensia.org/volumes/1988/stfrideswidenotes.pdf; Daphna Oren-Magidor, Infertility in Early Modern England (London: Palgrave Macmillan, 2017), 124–25, https://doi.org/10.1057/978-1-137-47668-5. The site remained of sufficient importance to gain reformers’ attention, the saint’s bones famously being combined with those of a laywoman in an attempt to prevent veneration.
Carole Levin, ‘St. Frideswide and St Uncumber: Changing Images of Female Saints in Renaissance England’, in Women, Writing, and the Reproduction of Culture in Tudor and Stuart Britain, ed. Mary Burke (Syracuse, NY: Syracuse University Press, 2000), 223–37. Contrary to Philip’s hopes, however, Frideswide never became a serious rival to Thomas Becket.

div.head: Manuscripts and their audiences
div.p: The complete text of Philip’s Miracula is preserved in a single manuscript, now Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Digby 177. The book is divided into short sections, and has been marked up for public reading. The manuscript was likely used as a liturgical book at St Frideswide’s Priory itself, with a series of nine readings marked out in the margins. The connection with the priory is secured by the additions and corrections to the manuscript, which represent later revisions by the author.

div.head: Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Digby 177
div.p:
Digby 177 is solely dedicated to Philip’s Miracula sancte Frideswide (BHL 3169). The changes to the text relating to John the Scot (fol. 2ra), discussed above, show that at least the first two quires (fols 1–16) were written between 1180 and 1183. Its Gothic script is the work of at least three different scribes. Modern scholars derived the title from the rubric heading the prologue, Incipit prologus domni Philippi prioris de miraculis sancte Frideswide. (Here begins the prologue of Dom Philip the prior on the miracles of St Frideswide.) The lack of any indication of the house where Philip held the office of prior immediately suggests that he was from the same institution as the intended destination of the book. Few miracle collections were widely copied, and a number of surviving volumes came directly from the shrine where the events described took place.
Bartlett, Saints and Worshippers from the Martyrs to the Reformation, 559–61.

The Digby manuscript has been described several times, and Andrew Watson was the first to tentatively propose it as an Oxford product, based on its provenance.
Thomas Duffus Hardy, Descriptive Catalogue of Materials Relating to the History of Great Britain and Ireland, to the End of the Reign of Henry VII, Rerum Britannicarum Medii Aevi Scriptores 26 (London: Longman, Green, Longman, and Roberts, 1862–1871), no. 1002; R. W. Hunt, Falconer Madan, and P. D. Record, A Summary Catalogue of Western Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library at Oxford (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1895–1953), no. 1778; W. D. Macray, Digby Manuscripts, ed. R. W. Hunt and Andrew G. Watson, Bodleian Library Quarto Catalogues 9 (Oxford: Bodleian Library, 1999), col. 190, with addenda at p. 82. The mathematician Thomas Allen (d. 1632) left the book to Sir Kenelm Digby (1603–65).
Allen’s MS fº 7: Andrew G. Watson, ‘Thomas Allen of Oxford and His Manuscripts’, in Medieval Scribes, Manuscripts and Libraries: Essays Presented to N. R. Ker, ed. M. B. Parkes and Andrew G. Watson (London: Scolar Press, 1978), 311; Allen/Digby inventory A 14, with pressmarks and signature on fol. 1r: Macray, Digby Manuscripts, 162. Allen acquired many other manuscripts from Oxford.
Watson, ‘Thomas Allen of Oxford and His Manuscripts’, 284–86; Macray, Digby Manuscripts, 82. He was also a Roman Catholic, and several of his books came from former shrines.
Michael Foster, ‘Thomas Allen (1540–1632), Gloucester Hall and the Survival of Catholicism in Post-Reformation Oxford’, Oxoniensia 46 (1981): 109–10, https://oxoniensia.org/volumes/1981/foster.pdf. This information alone, however, has not been considered sufficient to establish the manuscript’s origin.

The first matter of doubt is the manuscript’s extent, and whether Philip’s Miracula was always the only text in the volume. Its thirty leaves are 272–76 mm in height by 191–200 mm in width. The worn first page and the fourteenth-century additions on last page suggest that the book has travelled in this form since at least this time. The book might have been purposely conceived with the intent of allowing the addition of more miracles: it is collated 1–38 (fols 1–24), 46 (fols 25–30; the third leaf, fol. 27, was excised and replaced during production, with fols 27v–28r labelled a and b at the foot).
The flyleaves are blank modern parchment bifolia. The first leaf of each quire is lettered a–d at the foot in seventeenth-century ink: only the tops of these letters are visible due to trimming. Additional miracles were added to the last quire ad hoc, with the hand shifting several times. The ruling of fols 29r–30r is darker than elsewhere in the manuscript, and presumably these would have originally been blank.

The manuscript’s corrections not only establish its contemporaneity with the author but also suggest Philip’s involvement in the manuscript’s production. Scribes initially corrected the manuscript as they worked, with a number of pencilled emendations in the margins correcting minor slips and executed using the same script and shade of ink. Later on, someone with a much bolder approach and working at some distance from the original production made more extensive changes (compare fols 25r and 27r with fol. 28r, where the corrections are in the original shade of ink). These are executed in a darker shade of ink that facilitates their identification. This hand most notably adds the final section (ch. 106, fols 28v–30r), describing what is presented as the resurrection of a prominent citizen’s son, Laurence Kepeharm, after a gruesome surgery. This is written in Philip’s voice, but in a notably different hand from the rest of the manuscript, and with different usage in word division, abbreviation, and spelling from the earlier parts of the text, such as the spelling Oxonefordie rather than Oxen-. The chapter is much longer than any other in the text, but stylistically it is still plausible as Philip’s work. At the same time, the corrector undertook a fairly extensive round of revision on the manuscript. Nearly everything executed by this pen is an improvement to the text rather than something likely to be a correction based on an exemplar. It often appears to be executing directions pencilled in the margin; an extended note at the foot of fols 15v–16r is contemporary, and might have been a draft for one of the chapters, but is now illegible. This suggests that the darker ink is not Philip’s autograph, but a corrector working under his direction.

This revision also aimed to make the manuscript easier to use in oral delivery, evidently even by those who were less skilled in Latin. It spells out the exact wording of large numerals in the margins of fols 1v–2r, not because they were incorrect as written, but to make them easier to read aloud without hesitation. Its additional punctuation marks is quite different from the system of punctuation originally used in the manuscript, which is fairly sparse. The focus of the newer marks is on directing where one should pause in reading, usually inking points where there were already vertical bars marked in plummet. Accentuation is also added on occasion to show the correct word stress. The original punctuation has a more paratactic style that uses a minimalist approach to bracket long phrases, relying on the reader’s comprehension of the Latin to mark smaller divisions. This is easier to read visually (and for this reason, this edition suppresses most of the newer punctuation), while the added marks are a blunter instrument to address dim lighting and foggy minds.

Further evidence of the volume’s use for public reading is found in a series of marginal annotations that mark out specific passages as a series of readings. A formal series of notes shows a cycle of nine readings, each beginning with a number. If it is not immediately followed by another reading, it ends with the phrase Tu autem, short for Tu autem domine miserere nobis (But thou, O Lord, have mercy upon us), the phrase used at the end of lections. These create a series focusing on the translation and the miracles resulting from it at the priory, notably focusing on miracles associated with a particular festival:

item.p: Scripturus itaque … tuorum super omnia aromata, fols 1vb–2ra (ch. 1, Frideswide’s translation).

Cum igitur ut predictum … remanerent uestigia, fols 2vb–3rb (chs 5–6, the daughter of Geoffrey Pady healed of a swollen neck, the night following the translation; Alice of Oxfordshire healed of blindness on Maundy Thursday, 17 April 1180).
Erat in uico quodam cui uocabulum … ipsa rerum experientia didicimus, fols 3va–4ra (ch. 8, William of Ardley cured of various ailments).
Per idem tempus … et tedio affecerat inmanitas, fol. 4ra–va (ch. 9, the knight Haimo de Saint-Cyr cured on Easter, 20 April 1180).
Ad laudem insuper diuine pietatis … ubi munus curationis acceperat, fols 6vb–7va (ch. 20, William of Lincoln healed of paralysis).
Hoc quoque relatu … prorsus et inmunem, fols 7vb–8rb (ch. 22, Eustace of Coleshill cured of madness on the Invention of the Cross, 3 May).
Sed et de hoc quod eodem die … reformante momentis, fols 8rb–9ra (ch. 23, Fulk Grove’s son returned to life on the Invention of the Cross).
Puella quedam Emelina nomine … et corpore herens et affectu (opening indicator erased), fols 9vb–10va (ch. 28, Emmeline of Eddington saved from suicide and able to speak, May 1180).
Nec uacat a laude uirginis … sue testimonio roborantes (no Tu autem), fols 15ra–va? (ch. 42, Matilda of Northampton healed of blindness on Pentecost, 8 June 1180?).

div.p: These readings were not the only sections read from the book: reading aids are added in both plummet and the darker shade of ink in many passages throughout the text. Adjacent to several passages marked in this fashion is a further set of numbers added lightly in the margins, marking out another set of readings or perhaps instructions for copying passages into a lectionary: iii, fol. 10rb; iii, fol. 17rb; iiii, fol. 17va; iii, fol. 18ra; iiii and viii, fol. 18rb. The book was used extensively by a community wishing to read out the miracles of Frideswide, and this most obviously points to the priory itself.

Philip’s text may have quickly outgrown the manuscript. There are several passages in the text marked for removal in a contemporary hand, marked uacat (let it be removed), following the usual scribal practice of writing ua in the margin beside the beginning of the offending passage and cat at the end. These signs strike out Philip’s discourse on confession in chapter 43 and the unusually lengthy chapter 106, promoting evenness of style. These changes could have been intended primarily for readers, but might also point to the text being copied into a larger collection. Whatever the intent, the many changes to Digby 177 show that the text was subject to a series of revisions after its initial production, and by someone intimately familiar with the text’s details.

The volume continued in use after the twelfth century, as shown by two additions on the final page (fol. 30v). The first is an acrostic poem on fridesvvide, outlining some of her more famous miracles, not all of which appear in either Robert’s life or Philip’s work. The second item is a series of distinctions, providing words relating to the miracles of Frideswide, set in hexameter, and setting them against the seven vices.

div.head: The Romsey Legendary, London, British Library, Lansdowne MS 436
div.p:
The Romsey Legendary (London, British Library, Lansdowne MS 436), a collection of British saints’ lives from the first half of the fourteenth century, also includes extracts from Philip’s Miracula.
Paul Grosjean, ‘Vita S. Roberti novi monasterii in Anglia abbatis’, Analecta Bollandiana 56 (1938): 335–39, https://doi.org/10.1484/j.abol.4.00814; M. J. Wright, ‘BL MS Lansdowne 436 Contains Two Separate Items’, Notes and Queries 59, no. 1 (March 2012): 25–28, https://doi.org/10.1093/notesj/gjr283; Stephanie Hollis, ‘The Literary Culture of the Anglo-Saxon Royal Nunneries: Romsey and London, British Library, MS Lansdowne 436’, in Nuns’ Literacies in Medieval Europe: The Hull Dialogue, ed. Virginia Blanton, Veronica O’Mara, and Patricia Stoop, Medieval Women: Texts and Contexts 26 (Turnhout: Brepols, 2013), 169–83, https://doi.org/10.1484/m.mwtc.1.101525 discuss the manuscript. Each saint in the collection is given a short text, divided into several chapters mostly consisting of extracts from other works. The compiler sometimes even gives the titles of the volumes used. It is an open question whether the author obtained the extracts over the course of extensive research trips or through correspondence. A chronicle has been added to the beginning of the collection, and quires are missing from both the beginning and the end: the manuscript is collated i (fol. 1) | 14 (fols 2–5) | 36 (fols 6–11), 4–188 (fols 12–131), with a medieval foliation 3–127 beginning at fol. 6 (skipping fol. 23). A table of contents was added to the verso of the first folio, outlining the saints covered in the volume.

The book once belonged to Romsey Abbey, a house of Benedictine nuns. Its saints are not given a particularly prominent position in the collection, which makes it questionable whether the book originated at the abbey. Nonetheless, it was certainly there before the end of the fourteenth century, when it was inscribed Romesey (fol. 1r). The same hand also annotates the text, notably in the life of one of the abbey’s dedicatees, St Elfleda (fols 43v–45v), where the abbey itself is prominently mentioned (fol. 43v). There is also a late fifteenth-century inscription, Iste liber est de librario \ecclesie/ sancte Marie et sancte Ethelflede uirginis. de Romesey (fol. 1r). It later belonged to the Irish historian Sir James Ware (1594–1666), eventually entering the Lansdowne collection by a complex route.
William O’Sullivan, ‘A Finding List of Sir James Ware’s Manuscripts’, Proceedings of the Royal Irish Academy 97C, no. 2 (1997): 81, https://jstor.org/stable/25516189.

The legendary gives a four-chapter summary (fols 101r–104r) of Frideswide’s life (BHL 3166), followed by an otherwise unknown account of the invention of her relics (ch. 5, printed above). It abbreviates Philip’s work at fols 103v–104r, beginning with a version of his translation account, followed by with statistics on the sorts of miracles found in the Miracula (ch. 6), and concluding with an abbreviation of Philip’s chapter 36 as a sample of what he wrote (ch. 7). The Lansdowne compiler certainly worked from the full text of Digby 177, referring to it as Philip’s Liber translationis et miraculorum beate uirginis Frideswide (fol. 103vb). This was likely the Digby manuscript itself: there are few copying errors,
Blair, ‘Frideswide’, 118–19 shows the variants in the translation account between the two manuscripts. and even the punctuation and capitalization is similar. The statistics that the compiler provides on the miracles shows that it was the surviving collection, not an expanded or expurgated version, to which this title refers (notably listing two resurrection miracles, presumably chapters 23 and 106, the latter of which is marked for deletion in the manuscript).
Romsey Legendary, Frideswide, ch. 6, Lansdowne MS 436, fol. 103vb:
Scribit autem dominus Philippus loci illius tempore translationis beate uirginis ut dictum est prior de hiis que tempore suo \ibidem/ acciderunt miraculis inter cetera lumen amissum recuperasse⸵ tredecim conualuisse eciam sex paraliticis. ydropicos tres. furicosos seu mente alienatos nouem. febricitantos multos. mutos tres. surdos quinque leprosimi unum. contractos undecim. Multi eciam infirmi de uita desperati⸵ sani effecti sunt. Duo eciam morti reuixerunt. Alia eciam innumera miracula memorie digna scribit predictus prior. in libro translacionis et miraculorum beate uirginis Frideswide. quorum tantum unum causa breuitatis sensuimus fore hic subnectendum.
The only hint that the Lansdowne and Digby manuscripts might be independent witnesses to a common source occurs in the translation account, where there is an added phrase describing Frideswide’s shrine, ad hoc decenter ornato (fittingly decorated for this purpose). It is more likely, in light of the sorts of changes that the Lansdowne compiler makes elsewhere, that the phrase is an editorial embellishment. Although the Lansdowne manuscript is not an independent witness, it shows that Philip’s work was of interest beyond Oxford itself.

div.head: Editions of the Miracles
div.p:
Until the nineteenth century, Philip’s Miracula sancte Frideswide was known only to a few antiquarians. Anthony Wood used it for his Survey in 1661–66, and Thomas Hearne made extracts of names in the text in 1716.
Wood, Survey of the Antiquities of the City of Oxford, 2:141–178; D. W. Rannie, Remarks and Collections of Thomas Hearne, vol. 5, Oxford Historical Society 42 (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1901), 164, http://archive.org/details/hearneremarks42oxfouoft. It first appeared in print in 1853, edited by Benjamin Bossue (1804–82) as part of the Acta Sanctorum series, but with significant inaccuracies.
Benjamin Bossue, ‘Appendix ad acta S. Frideswidæ. De libro miraculorum eius, auctore Philippo Priore’, in Acta Sanctorum Octobris, ed. Joseph van Heck et al., vol. 8 (Brussels: Alphonse Greuse, 1853), 567–90, https://archive.org/details/actasanctorumquo56boll. John Blair has also edited Philip’s account of the translation.
Blair, ‘Frideswide’, 118–19. The present edition aims to present Philip’s text in a form that reflects the manuscript’s historical context.

Given the close association of Digby 177 with the text’s author, this edition of Philip’s Miracula follows the manuscript as closely as possible, correcting the text only to remove errors that inhibit comprehension. Spelling is reproduced from the original, even in its inconsistencies. The scribes are not always consistent in word division: where there is more than one acceptable usage, the one most consistently found in the manuscript is adopted (hence non nunquam, non nisi, and et si, but proculdubio). As in many manuscripts of this period, prepositions such as in and per are often joined with the following word, and even hyphenated as one word across a line break (e.g. infaciem, fol. 8ra). Not all the manuscript’s scribes follow this practice, and this edition normalizes such phrases to modern usage. Scribal corrections are always noted. Some passages in the manuscript have additional annotations to assist oral delivery: acute accents are often added to show where stress should be placed, and sometimes vertical bars are lightly added to bracket phrasing.
